literallayout.computeroutput: 1 #ifndef InhomogenousTransformationRectangleFlag 2 #define InhomogenousTransformationRectangleFlag 3 4 #include <deal.II/base/point.h> 5 #include <deal.II/base/tensor.h> 6 #include <deal.II/lac/vector.h> 7 #include <math.h> 8 #include <vector> 9 10 #include "../Core/Sector.h" 11 #include "../Core/Waveguide.h" 12 13 using namespace dealii; 14 15 /** 16 * \class InhomogenousTransformationRectangle 17 * \brief In this case we regard a rectangular waveguide and the effects on the 18 * material tensor by the space transformation and the boundary condition PML 19 * may overlap (hence inhomogenous space transformation) 20 * 21 * If this kind of boundary condition works stably we will also be able to deal 22 * with more general settings (which might for example incorporate angles in 23 * between the output and input connector. \author Pascal Kraft \date 28.11.2016 24 */ 25 26 class InhomogenousTransformationRectangular : public SpaceTransformation { 27 public: 28 InhomogenousTransformationRectangular(int); 29 30 virtual ~InhomogenousTransformationRectangular(); 31 32 Point<3> math_to_phys(Point<3> coord) const; 33 34 Point<3> phys_to_math(Point<3> coord) const; 35 36 bool is_identity(Point<3> coord) const; 37 38 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> get_Tensor(Point<3> &coordinate) const; 39 40 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> get_Preconditioner_Tensor( 41 Point<3> &coordinate, int block) const; 42 43 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> Apply_PML_To_Tensor( 44 Point<3> &coordinate, Tensor<2, 3, double> Tensor_input) const; 45 46 Tensor<2, 3, std::complex<double>> Apply_PML_To_Tensor_For_Preconditioner( 47 Point<3> &coordinate, Tensor<2, 3, double> Tensor_input, int block) const; 48 49 Tensor<2, 3, double> get_Space_Transformation_Tensor( 50 Point<3> &coordinate) const; 51 52 Tensor<2, 3, double> get_Space_Transformation_Tensor_Homogenized( 53 Point<3> &coordinate) const; 54 55 const double XMinus, XPlus, YMinus, YPlus, ZMinus, ZPlus; 56 57 /** 58 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 59 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 60 * x-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 61 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 62 * presence of a PML-Material. 63 */ 64 bool PML_in_X(Point<3> &position) const; 65 66 /** 67 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 68 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 69 * y-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 70 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 71 * presence of a PML-Material. 72 */ 73 bool PML_in_Y(Point<3> &position) const; 74 75 /** 76 * This function is used to determine, if a system-coordinate belongs to a 77 * PML-region for the PML that limits the computational domain along the 78 * z-axis. Since there are 3 blocks of PML-type material, there are 3 79 * functions. \param position Stores the position in which to test for 80 * presence of a PML-Material. 81 */ 82 bool PML_in_Z(Point<3> &position) const; 83 84 /** 85 * Similar to the PML_in_Z only this function is used to generate the 86 * artificial PML used in the Preconditioner. These Layers are not only 87 * situated at the surface of the computational domain but also inside it at 88 * the interfaces of Sectors. 89 */ 90 bool Preconditioner_PML_in_Z(Point<3> &p, unsigned int block) const; 91 92 /** 93 * This function fulfills the same purpose as those with similar names but it 94 * is supposed to be used together with Preconditioner_PML_in_Z instead of the 95 * versions without "Preconditioner". 96 */ 97 double Preconditioner_PML_Z_Distance(Point<3> &p, unsigned int block) const; 98 99 /** 100 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 101 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 102 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 103 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 104 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 105 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 106 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 107 * PML-surface. 108 */ 109 double PML_X_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 110 111 /** 112 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 113 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 114 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 115 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 116 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 117 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 118 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 119 * PML-surface. 120 */ 121 122 double PML_Y_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 123 /** 124 * This function calculates for a given point, its distance to a PML-boundary 125 * limiting the computational domain. This function is used merely to make 126 * code more readable. There is a function for every one of the dimensions 127 * since the normal vectors of PML-regions in this implementation are the 128 * coordinate-axis. This value is set to zero outside the PML and positive 129 * inside both PML-domains (only one for the z-direction). \param position 130 * Stores the position from which to calculate the distance to the 131 * PML-surface. 132 */ 133 double PML_Z_Distance(Point<3> &position) const; 134 135 /** 136 * This member contains all the Sectors who, as a sum, form the complete 137 * Waveguide. These Sectors are a partition of the simulated domain. 138 */ 139 std::vector<Sector<2>> case_sectors; 140 141 /** 142 * The material-property \f$\epsilon_r\f$ has a different value inside and 143 * outside of the waveguides core. This variable stores its value inside the 144 * core. 145 */ 146 const double epsilon_K; 147 /** 148 * The material-property \f$\epsilon_r\f$ has a different value inside and 149 * outside of the waveguides core. This variable stores its value outside the 150 * core. 151 */ 152 const double epsilon_M; 153 /** 154 * Since the computational domain is split into subdomains (called sectors), 155 * it is important to keep track of the amount of subdomains. This member 156 * stores the number of Sectors the computational domain has been split into. 157 */ 158 const int sectors; 159 160 /** 161 * This value is initialized with the value Delta from the input-file. 162 */ 163 const double deltaY; 164 165 /** 166 * At the beginning (before the first solution of a system) only the boundary 167 * conditions for the shape of the waveguide are known. Therefore the values 168 * for the degrees of freedom need to be estimated. This function sets all 169 * variables to appropiate values and estimates an appropriate shape based on 170 * averages and a polynomial interpolation of the boundary conditions on the 171 * shape. 172 */ 173 void estimate_and_initialize(); 174 175 /** 176 * This member calculates the value of Q1 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 177 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 178 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 179 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q1 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 180 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 181 * function. 182 */ 183 double get_Q1(double z) const; 184 185 /** 186 * This member calculates the value of Q2 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 187 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 188 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 189 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q2 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 190 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 191 * function. 192 */ 193 double get_Q2(double z) const; 194 195 /** 196 * This member calculates the value of Q3 for a provided \f$z\f$-coordinate. 197 * This value is used in the transformation of the solution-vector in 198 * transformed coordinates (solution of the system-matrix) to real coordinates 199 * (physical field). \param z The value of Q3 is independent of \f$x\f$ and 200 * \f$y\f$. Therefore only a \f$z\f$-coordinate is provided in a call to the 201 * function. 202 */ 203 double get_Q3(double z) const; 204 205 /** 206 * This is a getter for the values of degrees of freedom. A getter-setter 207 * interface was introduced since the values are estimated automatically 208 * during the optimization and non-physical systems should be excluded from 209 * the domain of possible cases. \param dof The index of the degree of freedom 210 * to be retrieved from the structure of the modelled waveguide. \return This 211 * function returns the value of the requested degree of freedom. Should this 212 * dof not exist, 0 will be returnd. 213 */ 214 double get_dof(int dof) const; 215 216 /** 217 * This function sets the value of the dof provided to the given value. It is 218 * important to consider, that some dofs are non-writable (i.e. the values of 219 * the degrees of freedom on the boundary, like the radius of the 220 * input-connector cannot be changed). \param dof The index of the parameter 221 * to be changed. \param value The value, the dof should be set to. 222 */ 223 void set_dof(int dof, double value); 224 225 /** 226 * This is a getter for the values of degrees of freedom. A getter-setter 227 * interface was introduced since the values are estimated automatically 228 * during the optimization and non-physical systems should be excluded from 229 * the domain of possible cases. \param dof The index of the degree of freedom 230 * to be retrieved from the structure of the modelled waveguide. \return This 231 * function returns the value of the requested degree of freedom. Should this 232 * dof not exist, 0 will be returnd. 233 */ 234 double get_free_dof(int dof) const; 235 236 /** 237 * This function sets the value of the dof provided to the given value. It is 238 * important to consider, that some dofs are non-writable (i.e. the values of 239 * the degrees of freedom on the boundary, like the radius of the 240 * input-connector cannot be changed). \param dof The index of the parameter 241 * to be changed. \param value The value, the dof should be set to. 242 */ 243 void set_free_dof(int dof, double value); 244 245 /** 246 * Returns the complete length of the computational domain. 247 */ 248 double System_Length() const; 249 250 /** 251 * Returns the length of one sector 252 */ 253 double Sector_Length() const; 254 255 /** 256 * Returns the length of one layer 257 */ 258 double Layer_Length() const; 259 260 /** 261 * Returns the radius for a system-coordinate; 262 */ 263 double get_r(double in_z) const; 264 265 /** 266 * Returns the shift for a system-coordinate; 267 */ 268 double get_m(double in_z) const; 269 270 /** 271 * Returns the tilt for a system-coordinate; 272 */ 273 double get_v(double in_z) const; 274 275 int Z_to_Layer(double) const; 276 277 /** 278 * This vector of values saves the initial configuration 279 */ 280 Vector<double> InitialDofs; 281 282 /** 283 * Other objects can use this function to retrieve an array of the current 284 * values of the degrees of freedom of the functional we are optimizing. This 285 * also includes restrained degrees of freedom and other functions can be used 286 * to determine this property. This has to be done because in different cases 287 * the number of restrained degrees of freedom can vary and we want no logic 288 * about this in other functions. 289 */ 290 Vector<double> Dofs() const; 291 292 /** 293 * This function returns the number of unrestrained degrees of freedom of the 294 * current optimization run. 295 */ 296 unsigned int NFreeDofs() const; 297 298 /** 299 * This function returns the total number of DOFs including restrained ones. 300 * This is the lenght of the array returned by Dofs(). 301 */ 302 unsigned int NDofs() const; 303 304 /** 305 * Since Dofs() also returns restrained degrees of freedom, this function can 306 * be applied to determine if a degree of freedom is indeed free or 307 * restrained. "restrained" means that for example the DOF represents the 308 * radius at one of the connectors (input or output) and therefore we forbid 309 * the optimization scheme to vary this value. 310 */ 311 bool IsDofFree(int) const; 312 313 /** 314 * Console output of the current Waveguide Structure. 315 */ 316 void Print() const; 317 318 std::complex<double> evaluate_for_z_with_sum(double, double, Waveguide *); 319 320 std::complex<double> evaluate_for_z(double z_in, Waveguide *); 321 }; 322 323 #endif
